body:
Hey @tolmasky! We really appreciate you taking the time to report an issue. The  collaborators on this project attempt to help as many people as  possible, but we're a limited number of volunteers, so it's  possible this won't be addressed swiftly.

If you need any help, or just have general Babel or JavaScript questions, we have a  vibrant [Slack community](https://babeljs.slack.com) that typically always has someone  willing to help. You can sign-up [here](https://slack.babeljs.io/) for an invite.

So the line in questions seems to be the following, in `stmtToDirective`:

https://github.com/babel/babel/blob/d5ba35586754da12ae406f6012b24d7f02ac17a6/packages/babel-parser/src/parser/statement.js#L162

Here, Babel is performing the inverse operation that I will eventually perform, turning a StringLiteral into a DirectiveLiteral. Except, instead of keeping the existing `value` from StringLiteral, it is explicitly choosing to set the value to the `raw` value minus the surrounding quotes, leaving the double-escaping. Is there a specific reason for this? I think just removing this "custom" value extrapolation would make this behave the way I originally expected it to.

Interestingly, the `estree` version of this code does precisely that, and thus has the "correct" (in my interpretation) behavior:

https://github.com/babel/babel/blob/2e2d202694df8ec485ac2bae79e5258b9e552fd9/packages/babel-parser/src/plugins/estree.js#L80

issue.title: fix(babel-parser): DirectiveLiteral contained improperly escaped string values.

issue.body: Closes #13953. Reviewed by @tolmasky. | Q ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† | A | ------------------------ | --- | Fixed Issues? | `Fixes #13953 ` | Patch: Bug Fix? | Yes | | Major: Breaking Change? | No | | Minor: New Feature? | No | | Tests Added + Pass? | Yes | Documentation PR Link | | Any Dependency Changes? | No | | License | MIT

body:
> It is explicitly choosing to set the value to the raw value minus the surrounding quotes, leaving the double-escaping. Is there a specific reason for this?

Yes, because
```
"us\u0065 strict";
```
should not be interpreted as a `"use strict"` directive. The spec requires a directive to be an [exact codepoint sequence](https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive), so we preserve the escape in its `value`, while the `value` of a StringLiteral corresponds to [SV](https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-static-semantics-sv) (the unescaped text) in the spec.

Ah, I see, I was interpreting that to mean to that you should be comparing the raw value (as in, doing .rawValue === ...). Makes sense. In that case is there a simple way to go from raw to "normal" value? JSON.parse is insufficient since JSON.parse does not allow for newlines in strings.

This is kind of tricky because the `StringLiteral` to `DirectiveLiteral` transformation drops the `value` information, the original generation of which seems non-trivial, requiring taking the `rawValue` and rerunning it through `Tokenizer.readString` (and thus `Tokenizer.readEscapedChar`) to replicate. It's a shame because this work *has* already been done, only to then be undone later. If there was a something like `unrawValue` or `stringValue` attached to the `extra` object of DirectiveLiteral then this would be very simple.

One additional point, the spec seems to only refer to escape sequences with respect to the `UseStrictDirective`, and not all directives. As far as I can tell, this restriction is only for "use strict", and left open to individual implementers for custom directives. I think this is a pretty good reason to have something like `stringValue` in the `DirectiveLiteral`'s `extra` object. Would there be opposition to adding this?

> left open to individual implementers for custom directives

Yes. Though the spec also mentions that

> If an appropriate notification mechanism exists, an implementation should issue a warning if it encounters in a Directive Prologue an ExpressionStatement that is not a Use Strict Directive and which does not have a meaning defined by the implementation.

so custom directives are in a limbo.

> extra.stringValue

That looks good to me, essentially moving https://github.com/babel/babel/blob/54c539ecc12a70706e642ef9354b2ece6360444a/packages/babel-parser/src/plugins/estree.js#L140 to the base parser. Do you want to open a PR?

issue.title: Always expose `expressionValue` in `DirectiveLiteral` nodes
